Great story, One of my favorite games

Fun game with lots of different challanges. Sometimes it was confusing to see where to go next, even to the point where I missed out on hidden stashes because what I thought was a hidden pathway, was actually the real way forward. I played a good number of hours on this, definitely not a short game. The story was alright, with fairly memorable main characters. "Gman" still creeps me out. I love the small comedic moments like interactions between NPCs and all the stuff they say when you talk to them. I think my favourite line is "Sometimes I dream about cheese." Same, fellow random citizen, same. You gotta love the vortigaunts in this game too, I find them very lovable. (Mild spoiler) [spoiler] It's a shame they're enslaved in this game. [/spoiler]
I loove fucking around (exploring) a lot in games and it was pretty easy to do that. But man, [b] FUCK [/b] those spider-looking poison headcrabs. I can never hear a squeaky sound without being moderately filled with fear, ever again.

I give Half Life 2 a 5.7 out of 10.
Great combination of platforming, puzzle-solving, and shooting. Game still holds up 17 Years later 10/10

Although Half-Life 2 is a very linear first person shooter, it is a classic of the genre and worth playing to experience the forerunner of modern shooters.

Why's a socially inept bloke monologuing at us? Why are we on a train? Why's Jeremy Corbyn talking on a big fizzy screen? Why are all these mildly threatening officers in unconventional uniforms sporting impractical gasmasks? So the world's been taken over by an alien force? They span entire dimensions and are larger than human comprehension allows proper processing for? Why am I not really getting that vibe? Why do all the people in this place speak the same language? Why have alleged Black Mesa scientists been relocated to the same place at the same time? Why are they all acting like we know them? How've they all set up several labs undetected by scanner bots? Why is this starting to sound a bit like contrived bullsḣit? Why's the lesbian in the leather jacket so bloody okay with everything, as if Earth being taken over was just that someone put a coffee down on her table and left an ugly ring on it? Where's this sudden driving section come from? Why is it being stopped every few feet to solve easy — and I hesitate to use this word — puzzles, creating a flow akin to that of Michael J. Fox attempting to operate a forklift? To show off the physics engine? Haven't we already seen enough of that by watching how objects interact of our own accord? What's this glowy orange diḷdo gun? Why should I use it if it doesn't shoot things? It conserves ammo and solves physics puzzles? Doesn't the crowbar do that a hundred times better? Some props are an instant kill when used in tandem with the Grabbity Gun? What's a prop? Is that a fancy word the Half-Life community uses to mean 'object'? Hasn't something gone wrong if I'm filled with dread seeing a wide open area with a car politely waiting in it, remembering what the last driving section was like? What's the map name for the next chapter so I can skip to it? Why is it more of this boḷlocks except there's not a car anymore? Should this bit with all the cell blocks really be the only part where I've extracted amusement from for the simple reason that it seemed to take some notes from Half-Life 1 more than any other part of the game has? Oh for fuƈk's sake, why is Alyx here? Why'd she hold her fire just for me when she's already shot all these? Isn't she a bit underdressed to poke about in an area with a high density of flying bullets? So now she's a bullet sponge as well as a mechanic and a hacker? Is there anything she can't do? Why have I forgotten how the rest of the game goes and why do I think I know the answer? Why did the priest have to be the only cool "character"?

BEST GAME EVER

What a game! Where other games like Resident Evil 4 and even the first Mass Effect are starting to show their age, there's just something about Half Life 2 that refuses to get old.

1. Graphics. The graphics certainly aren't what I would call modern, being a nearly 20 year old game. But there's a lot of polish to them, cull distance for example is simply non-existent, likely hidden behind clever level design where level transitions allow for a sort of visual trick that you never actually see or notice the next part of the level loading in. There's also no texture popping, a problem that seems to have actually gotten worse over time in modern games. The character models still look great, something that some games still struggle with, and animations overall are pretty fluid, and fit well into the universe. Enemy designs still hold up, from the shambling headcrab zombies to the hanging barnacles waiting to pull you up. This was one of the best looking games of all time in 2004, and it still holds up where many of its time have aged.

2. Gameplay: This is the part where Half-Life 2 really refuses to age. The combat and shooting is as tight as ever, but it's the physics engine that really pushes the gameplay above and beyond what most first person shooter games are accomplishing even today. There's little stuff like weighing down a ramp so you can walk up it to advance, or stacking boxes to reach a ladder, cool stuff but can come across as gimmicky. Where it really shines is when you get the Gravity Gun, allowing you to launch objects at enemies, like red barrels, manhacks, even their own grenades. With the impressive arsenal, environmental cues and the gravity gun, there's a lot of opportunity for each gamer to experiment with combat differently, so it never feels like the same fight in another room. Overall, Half-Life still has more compelling combat than most modern FPS games, matched only by games like Bioshock and Dishonered. 

If there's anyone out there who hasn't played this game yet, you must. It's not as dated as it might seem, and might just feel more modern than you think.

During the Winter Sale, I saw that the entire Half-Life Franchise was on sale. I have never played a single-player Valve game, so I really didn't know what to expect. When I played the first Half-Life with both expansion packs several weeks ago, I thought that even though the graphics are outdated this game was amazing. When I booted up Half-Life 2 for the first time, I was in awe. The graphics are okay by today's standards, but amazing for Half-Life. The mechanics are refreshing and nice, the gunplay is smooth, and hitboxes are accurate. I can now pick things up with "E" and I can follow along this continuation of an already amazing story,

When I first realised that you can pick things up, and throw them, I spent my first 20 minutes throwing cans I got from the vending machines at NPCs. Buy this game. 

Now I want to buy a VR headset JUST for Half-Life Alyx. Curse you Valve.

I don't go into games with this much hype with massive expectations. Nostalgia can blind a person, especially for a game closing in on 20 years old. But this is legitimately one of the better games I've ever played. It holds up incredibly well, and is honestly such a blast to play through. It's seriously worth giving a shot, even if you're not really into FPS games like I was when I picked it up (I am now though!)

Es impresionante que un juego con una narrativa tan presente, nos cuente su historia casi sin cinemáticas, haciendo que realmente juguemos el 99% de ella, con la excepción de unas pocas escenas. La historia continua la del juego anterior, esta vez mostrándonos una distopía en la que un estado totalitario transhumanista oprime a la población. Está ambientada en Europa del este (aunque todos hablen inglés).

El gameplay es similar al de su predecesor, pero está vez contamos con un nuevo sistema de físicas, dando lugar a puzzles más orientados a estas mismas, y a una nueva arma (Gravity Gun) que puede controlar la gravedad de varios objetos, haciéndolos levitar, atrayéndolos, o empujándolos (estilo jedi). Tanto los puzzles de física como la Gravity Gun encajan bien con el protagonista, ya que se supone que es un Dr. en Física teórica.

Um dos melhores jogos que eu já joguei.

Half-Life 2 como uma sequência do título original entrega uma experiência incrível como seu antecessor. As mecânicas e físicas do jogo são fantásticas, a música pega o tempo dos momentos na hora certa e toda a jogabilidade é muito divertida.

A temática do jogo é focada em um futuro distópico onde a humanidade vive sob a ditadura do regime Combine (raça alienígena), e assim Gordon Freeman após os eventos do jogo original aparece para se juntar a resistência e lutar pela liberdade dos humanos.

HL2 é excelente e vale muito a pena conhecer.

Half Life 2, un clasico de Valve y de los videojuegos en general, una secuela que lleva a cabo lo mejor del primer Half life y lo lleva al siguiente nivel, mejores graficos, mejor jugabilidad y se podria decir que hasta mejor historia. 
Los graficos: Los graficos de este juego son simplemente alucinantes contando el año en el que se lanzo este juego, aunque a pesar de la diferencia de años entre el presente se mantubo muuuy bien.
Jugabilidad: Que falta por decir a cerca de la jugabilidad excelente que tiene Half Life 2, buenas mecanicas no muy complejas de entender y llevar a cabo. 
Variedad de Armas: La variedad de armas en este Half Life supera con creces al anterior, no solo en variedad sino tambien en diseño, muy bien hechas y balanceadas.
Modelos de Personajes: Muy buenos a decir verdad, no me he encontrado con ninguna falla de textura o que tarden en cargar. Las caras de las personas y el cuerpo de estos estan muy bien realizados y no fallan.
La Historia: Esto es uno de los puntos mas fuertes de Half Life 2 y en el cual se ve la superioridad de esta secuela de la primera entrega y me atrevo a decir que tiene mejor historia que algunos de los juegos que se lanzan actualmente, tanto indies como AAA.
En definitiva y en resumidas cuentas, un juegazo que marco un antes y un despues en el ambiente de los videojuegos, sus excelentes graficos,  buena juagabilidad y la historia hacen de este uno de los mejores juegos de la historia. 10/10.

While a little linear for most people's tastes, it is hard to deny that Half Life 2 is one of the most influential games of all time. Even if you aren't a fan of the fps genre, this game still hold up amazingly well today and serves as a monument to Valve's quality.

NOTE: THIS REVIEW WILL CONTAIN SPOILERS FOR HALF-LIFE 2 AND 1 BY AN EXTENT.

I want to give my thoughts on this game; before I start this review I would like to say that I did enjoy Half-Life 2. It improves on the already great game that was Half-Life 1 and adds an extra layer or detail to it that at the time was groundbreaking for the industry. I wanted to give my in depth thoughts on this game as I have mixed feelings when it comes to a few aspects in the game. 

Firstly, let's start off with the plot. Half-Life 2 picks up right after Half-Life 1. After the resonance cascade of the first game, Gordon is employed by the Gman and is put in stasis until he’s needed again. You start the game with a short monologue from the Gman, stating that your time has finally come again. You then get transported into a tram sequence, similar to the first game: however this time, very different. You arrive in a city overrun by an alien species known as the Combine. The Combine are a force to be reckoned with within Half-Life, they grounded every military on earth to dust within 7 hours. The game from here is you and the resistance (a group who has taken on the task of eliminating the combine) trying to weaken the combine so you can finally get them off earth for good. The plot is easy to follow, yet complex in many ways; the further details given to you about the combine throughout the game really make you feel like this is a world in need of an uprising; it motivates the player to continue fighting with the resistance. The plot is very good and would only get better as the series progressed. Even though Half-Life 1 had very good story telling, it can’t compete with the narrative that Half-Life 2 conveys. Out of everything in Half-Life 2, this is the part I have the least problems with. 

Secondly we will talk about the gameplay. The gameplay of Half-Life 2 is largely similar to Half-Life 1. You gather an arsenal overtime to help aid you take down the enemy. This is a simple example of ‘if it ain’t broke, don’t fix it’. The weaponry in Half-Life 2 makes you feel so powerful, almost on a similar level to how Doom makes you feel when you're killing enemies. The gunplay feels great. Every weapon is unique and will always help aid you in many different ways. You also have a Health and Power which act as a key in your survival. Health is standard like in most games and Power is more of an Armour feature where it can block damage. I know that they are simple features, but they compliment each other so well. You will find however that you will lose health, power and ammo quite quickly; this will make the player constantly scramble to find them two things. This was also in Half-Life 1 to an extent, however in Half-Life 1 it was annoying not because of the feature itself, it was mainly due to the fact that when you die you would have to go back a large chunk of the game if you didn’t save. The same thing happens here in 2, however you can just spam quicksave every 10 seconds which is what I mainly did. Another aspect to the gameplay that I really liked is the physics Half-Life 2 holds. I cannot explain how fun it is to kill enemies with the Gravity Gun or just explode a random barrel to kill 3 Combine Soldiers in a row. The physics compliment the fighting in the game and it honestly makes you feel even more powerful than before. 

Thirdly, I want to discuss puzzles in the game. This is the aspect I had the most issues with. In Half-Life 2 (just like Half-Life 1), it will slow you down to solve a puzzle every once in a while. These puzzles can range from either good to just irritating. Some of these puzzles are just so cryptic that I kept having to look up guides for multiple puzzles in this game. It’s not to say outright crap or make the game worse because of it. Generally once you have done the puzzle, you’ll be back to strafing around enemies in no time. It’s just something that really bothered me and it honestly just slowed the pace of the game down a lot for me.

I overall like Half-Life 2. It’s a great game with a good story and amazing gameplay, however the passing of the game can be a bit of a problem.
